G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction under G.L. c. 212, § 4, as this is a civil action in which the damages claimed exceed $25,000.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in Norfolk County pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1, because the events giving rise to this action occurred within this county.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff, as a business invitee, a duty to exercise reasonable care in maintaining its premises in a reasonably safe condition, to warn of and remedy known hazards, and to prevent foreseeable injuries. *See* Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973); Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass. 368 (2010).
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: The quoted portion is a concurring opinion focused on abandoning traditional entrant classifications (invitee, licensee, trespasser) and criticizing continued special treatment of trespassers. It does not set out or affirm the specific business-invitee duty described in the proposition. While the full Mounsey majority opinion does move toward a general reasonable-care standard for lawful visitors, this limited excerpt does not clearly articulate the particular duty to business invitees claimed in the proposition.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that ‘trespassers’ stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential."

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff, as a business invitee, a duty to exercise reasonable care in maintaining its premises in a reasonably safe condition, to warn of and remedy known hazards, and to prevent foreseeable injuries. *See* Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973); Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass. 368 (2010).
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion expressly describes the traditional Massachusetts rule that owners owe invitees a duty of reasonable care to keep premises in a reasonably safe condition, including to repair or remove dangers or at least warn of non‑obvious ones. Papadopoulos does not alter that general duty; instead, it abolishes the separate ‘natural vs. unnatural’ snow‑and‑ice limitation and applies the same reasonable‑care standard to snow and ice hazards. Thus, it supports the proposition that a business owes invitees a duty of reasonable care to maintain safe premises and address known hazards.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “If the plaintiff was an invitee… the property owner owed a duty to use reasonable care to keep the premises ‘in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ … This duty required a property owner to make reasonable efforts to repair or remove any dangerous conditions, or at least to warn against any dangers not either known to the invitee or obvious to any ordinarily intelligent person and of which the property owner knew or reasonably should have known.”

Jurado v. Gregory A. Robbins, M.D., P.C..raw_text: Jurado v. Gregory A. Robbins, M.D., P.C., 93 Mass. App. Ct. 773 (2018)
Jurado v. Gregory A. Robbins, M.D., P.C..proposition: Defendant’s breach of duty was the direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injuries and resulting losses. *See* Jurado v. Gregory A. Robbins, M.D., P.C., 93 Mass. App. Ct. 773 (2018).

Barry v. Beverly Enterprises-Mass., Inc..raw_text: Barry v. Beverly Enterprises-Mass., Inc., 418 Mass. 590 (1994)
Barry v. Beverly Enterprises-Mass., Inc..proposition: It was reasonably foreseeable that a patron traversing the hallway would slip and fall if the wet condition was not remedied. *See* Barry v. Beverly Enterprises-Mass., Inc., 418 Mass. 590 (1994).
Barry v. Beverly Enterprises-Mass., Inc..support_reasoning: The opinion does not state or imply that it was reasonably foreseeable a patron would slip and fall if the wet/icy condition was not remedied. Instead, the court holds the opposite: that there was insufficient evidence the defendant knew or should have known of the icy condition, and thus no breach of duty. The reasoning focuses on lack of notice and unforeseeability, so using this case to support the cited foreseeability proposition is inaccurate.
Barry v. Beverly Enterprises-Mass., Inc..relevant_excerpt: “Thus, a defendant who did not have a reasonable opportunity to discover and remedy a hazardous condition — that is, a defendant who had no actual or constructive knowledge of the allegedly hazardous condition so that it could not reasonably remove, or warn the plaintiff of, the danger — cannot be found to have violated its duty of care. … In sum, the jury could not reasonably have inferred that the defendant violated its duty of reasonable care by failing to remove the ice or to warn the plaintiff of a potential hazard.”

Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.raw_text: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165 (1973)
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.proposition: Defendant’s agents, servants, and/or employees had either actual or constructive notice of the dangerous condition and failed to act with reasonable care. *See* Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165 (1973).
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.support_reasoning: The case does discuss the duty of a premises controller to use due care and the need for actual or constructive notice of a dangerous condition. However, the holding is that the plaintiff’s evidence was insufficient to show that the defendant had actual or constructive notice of the foreign substance in time to remove it; the court orders judgment for the defendant. Thus, Oliveri is authority limiting liability where notice cannot be shown, not supporting a claim that the defendant’s agents had such notice and failed to act with reasonable care.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.relevant_excerpt: “Where a foreign substance on a floor or stairway causes the business visitor to fall and sustain injuries, he may prove the negligence of the defendant by proof that the defendant or his servant caused the substance to be there, or he may show that the defendant or his servants had actual knowledge of the existence of the foreign substance… In the more usual case, however, the plaintiff attempts to establish the defendant’s negligence by showing that the foreign substance was present… for such a length of time that the defendant should have known about it.… There is nothing to distinguish this case from the great majority of cases in which we have held that directed verdicts were required.”

Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540 (19.proposition: Defendant’s negligence directly caused Plaintiff’s bodily injury, associated medical expenses, loss of earnings, and pain and suffering. *See* Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540 (1982); Janosky v. Eastern Freight Ways, Inc., 390 Mass. 583 (1983); Toubiana v. Priestly Mut. Life Ins. Co., 402 Mass. 84 (1988); O'Sullivan v. Shaw, 431 Mass. 201 (2000); Dubois v. Town of Brookline, 388 Mass. 327 (1983); G.L. c. 231, § 85 (comparative negligence standard).
Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540 (19.support_reasoning: Payton v. Abbott Labs is a DES exposure/emotional distress and prenatal injury case addressing when emotional distress without physical harm is compensable and whether a child can sue for in utero injuries. It does not involve a standard negligence verdict where a defendant’s negligence is found to have directly caused a plaintiff’s bodily injury, medical expenses, lost earnings, and pain and suffering. The opinion instead assumes negligence and causation for purposes of certified questions and focuses on recoverability of emotional distress and prenatal injury, so it does not serve as authority for the broad causation-and-damages proposition stated.
Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540 (19.relevant_excerpt: “We note initially that neither the issue of negligence nor that of causation is before us. The certified question assumes both that the defendants were negligent, and that their negligence caused the plaintiffs' emotional distress.” (386 Mass. at 545).

Janosky v. Eastern Freight Ways, Inc., 3.raw_text: Janosky v. Eastern Freight Ways, Inc., 390 Mass. 583 (1983)
Janosky v. Eastern Freight Ways, Inc., 3.proposition: Defendant’s negligence directly caused Plaintiff’s bodily injury, associated medical expenses, loss of earnings, and pain and suffering. *See* Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540 (1982); Janosky v. Eastern Freight Ways, Inc., 390 Mass. 583 (1983); Toubiana v. Priestly Mut. Life Ins. Co., 402 Mass. 84 (1988); O'Sullivan v. Shaw, 431 Mass. 201 (2000); Dubois v. Town of Brookline, 388 Mass. 327 (1983); G.L. c. 231, § 85 (comparative negligence standard).
Janosky v. Eastern Freight Ways, Inc., 3.case_name: Samuels Pharmacy, Inc. v. Board of Registration in Pharmacy
Janosky v. Eastern Freight Ways, Inc., 3.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns administrative searches of a pharmacy, the availability of declaratory relief, and the need to exhaust administrative remedies. It does not involve a negligence action, bodily injury, medical expenses, loss of earnings, or pain and suffering, nor does it discuss causation standards in tort. Citing this case for the proposition that a defendant’s negligence directly caused a plaintiff’s bodily injury and related damages is therefore inapt.
Janosky v. Eastern Freight Ways, Inc., 3.relevant_excerpt: This case arises from an action brought in the Superior Court in the county of Suffolk by the plaintiffs, Samuels Pharmacy, Inc. (Samuels), and William M. Bagley, Jr., seeking a declaratory judgment that they were the victims of unlawful searches and seizures by the Massachusetts State police, and a permanent injunction restraining the defendant Board of Registration in Pharmacy (board) from using any evidence obtained as a result of the unlawful searches and seizures in administrative disciplinary proceedings now pending against the plaintiffs.

Toubiana v. Priestly Mut. Life Ins. Co.,.raw_text: Toubiana v. Priestly Mut. Life Ins. Co., 402 Mass. 84 (1988)
Toubiana v. Priestly Mut. Life Ins. Co.,.proposition: Defendant’s negligence directly caused Plaintiff’s bodily injury, associated medical expenses, loss of earnings, and pain and suffering. *See* Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540 (1982); Janosky v. Eastern Freight Ways, Inc., 390 Mass. 583 (1983); Toubiana v. Priestly Mut. Life Ins. Co., 402 Mass. 84 (1988); O'Sullivan v. Shaw, 431 Mass. 201 (2000); Dubois v. Town of Brookline, 388 Mass. 327 (1983); G.L. c. 231, § 85 (comparative negligence standard).
Toubiana v. Priestly Mut. Life Ins. Co.,.support_reasoning: The opinion is a wrongful death negligence case, but it ultimately holds that the defendant was not negligent as a matter of law and affirms judgment for the defendant. The court’s reasoning focuses on duty, foreseeability, and the obviousness of the risk; it does not find that defendant’s negligence directly caused any bodily injury or damages. Thus, Toubiana does not support the proposition that a defendant’s negligence directly caused plaintiff’s bodily injury and associated losses; it instead is authority for no negligence and hence no causation as to the defendant.
Toubiana v. Priestly Mut. Life Ins. Co.,.relevant_excerpt: “Thus, the jury was unwarranted in inferring that an ordinarily prudent person in the relevant circumstances would have provided a solid elevator ceiling or a printed warning concerning the danger of extending materials from the moving elevator into the elevator shaft. It follows that the defendant’s failure to adopt either of those measures did not constitute negligence.… Judgment affirmed.”

O'Sullivan v. Shaw, 431 Mass. 201 (2000).proposition: Defendant’s negligence directly caused Plaintiff’s bodily injury, associated medical expenses, loss of earnings, and pain and suffering. *See* Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540 (1982); Janosky v. Eastern Freight Ways, Inc., 390 Mass. 583 (1983); Toubiana v. Priestly Mut. Life Ins. Co., 402 Mass. 84 (1988); O'Sullivan v. Shaw, 431 Mass. 201 (2000); Dubois v. Town of Brookline, 388 Mass. 327 (1983); G.L. c. 231, § 85 (comparative negligence standard).
O'Sullivan v. Shaw, 431 Mass. 201 (2000).support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on duty and the open and obvious danger rule, holding that the defendants owed no duty to warn and therefore could not be liable for the plaintiff’s injuries. It does not discuss damages categories such as medical expenses, lost earnings, or pain and suffering, nor does it address a situation where negligence is established and causation of those damages is analyzed. Thus, it does not provide authority for the proposition that defendant’s negligence directly caused plaintiff’s bodily injury and related damages.
O'Sullivan v. Shaw, 431 Mass. 201 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “Before liability for negligence can be imposed, there must first be a legal duty owed by the defendant to the plaintiff, and a breach of that duty proximately resulting in the injury… We conclude that, because the danger of diving into the shallow end of a swimming pool is open and obvious to a person of average intelligence, the defendants had no duty to warn the plaintiff of this danger as a matter of law and, therefore, they could not be found liable for his injuries.”

Dubois v. Town of Brookline, 388 Mass. 3.raw_text: Dubois v. Town of Brookline, 388 Mass. 327 (1983)
Dubois v. Town of Brookline, 388 Mass. 3.proposition: Defendant’s negligence directly caused Plaintiff’s bodily injury, associated medical expenses, loss of earnings, and pain and suffering. *See* Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540 (1982); Janosky v. Eastern Freight Ways, Inc., 390 Mass. 583 (1983); Toubiana v. Priestly Mut. Life Ins. Co., 402 Mass. 84 (1988); O'Sullivan v. Shaw, 431 Mass. 201 (2000); Dubois v. Town of Brookline, 388 Mass. 327 (1983); G.L. c. 231, § 85 (comparative negligence standard).
Dubois v. Town of Brookline, 388 Mass. 3.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns statutory interpretation of Massachusetts paternity and nonsupport statutes (G.L. c. 273, §§ 12–18) and whether an adjudication of paternity under § 15 survives an acquittal on a nonsupport charge. It does not address negligence, causation, bodily injury, medical expenses, loss of earnings, or pain and suffering. Accordingly, Dubois v. Town of Brookline does not provide authority for the tort causation and damages proposition for which it is cited.
Dubois v. Town of Brookline, 388 Mass. 3.relevant_excerpt: “As we read the entire statutory scheme, § 15 is designed to provide criminal penalties for a parent who neglects or wilfully refuses to support.… Since § 15 provides for only one finding, and in this case that finding is not guilty, we remand the case to the jury-of-six session of the District Court, where the defendant’s motion to dismiss should be allowed.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Defendant’s negligence directly caused Plaintiff’s bodily injury, associated medical expenses, loss of earnings, and pain and suffering. *See* Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540 (1982); Janosky v. Eastern Freight Ways, Inc., 390 Mass. 583 (1983); Toubiana v. Priestly Mut. Life Ins. Co., 402 Mass. 84 (1988); O'Sullivan v. Shaw, 431 Mass. 201 (2000); Dubois v. Town of Brookline, 388 Mass. 327 (1983); G.L. c. 231, § 85 (comparative negligence standard).

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 6B and 6C.proposition: Plaintiff seeks compensation for all such losses, reasonable attorney’s fees and costs, and interest pursuant to G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B and 6C.
